items.title: Trump says he's fired Federal Reserve board member Lisa Cook
items.standfirst: President Trump said Monday he has fired Lisa Cook from the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors — a dramatic move after months of public attacks against the central bank.

items.title: Donald Trump moves to fire Fed governor Lisa Cook
items.standfirst: Departure of Cook, first Black woman to sit on central bank’s board, would allow US president to put forward a replacementDonald Trump has said he is firing the Federal Reserve governor, Lisa Cook, over allegations she committed mortgage fraud, in an extraordinary move that marks the latest escalation in the US president’s attack on the central bank’s independence.Trump wrote to Cook on Monday, telling her that he was removing her from her position “effective immediately”, based on the allegation from one of his allies that she had obtained a mortgage on a second home she incorrectly described as her primary residence. Continue reading...
items.content: Departure of Cook, first Black woman to sit on central bank’s board, would allow US president to put forward a replacementDonald Trump has said he is firing the Federal Reserve governor, Lisa Cook, over allegations she committed mortgage fraud, in an extraordinary move that marks the latest escalation in the US president’s attack on the central bank’s independence.Trump wrote to Cook on Monday, telling her that he was removing her from her position “effective immediately”, based on the allegation from one of his allies that she had obtained a mortgage on a second home she incorrectly described as her primary residence. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump fires Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook over mortgage loan allegations

items.title: What Trump’s firing of Fed governor means for central bank’s independence
items.standfirst: The US president fired Lisa Cook over mortgage fraud allegations – a move experts view as a means to exert more controlTrump says he is firing Lisa Cook over mortgage fraud claimsDonald Trump fired Lisa Cook, a Federal Reserve governor, late on Monday, in a move viewed as a sharp escalation in his battle to exert greater control over the independent institution.Trump said in a letter posted on his Truth Social platform that he is firing Cook because of allegations she committed mortgage fraud. The allegation was made last week by Bill Pulte, a Trump appointee to the Federal Housing Administration, an agency that regulates mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Continue reading...
items.content: The US president fired Lisa Cook over mortgage fraud allegations – a move experts view as a means to exert more controlTrump says he is firing Lisa Cook over mortgage fraud claimsDonald Trump fired Lisa Cook, a Federal Reserve governor, late on Monday, in a move viewed as a sharp escalation in his battle to exert greater control over the independent institution.Trump said in a letter posted on his Truth Social platform that he is firing Cook because of allegations she committed mortgage fraud. The allegation was made last week by Bill Pulte, a Trump appointee to the Federal Housing Administration, an agency that regulates mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says he's fired Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook
items.standfirst: President Trump announced Monday that he's fired Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook after months of public attacks against the central bank. In a letter posted on social media, Trump accused Cook of making false statements on mortgage documents, actions he claimed were "gross negligence" and "potentially criminal."
items.content: President Trump announced Monday that he's fired Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook after months of public attacks against the central bank. In a letter posted on social media, Trump accused Cook of making false statements on mortgage documents, actions he claimed were "gross negligence" and "potentially criminal."

items.title: Trump seeks to fire Fed governor Lisa Cook
items.standfirst: President Trump says he's firing Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, after a Trump ally accused Cook of making false statements on a mortgage application. The president's authority to remove a Fed governor may be challenged in court.
items.content: President Trump says he's firing Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, after a Trump ally accused Cook of making false statements on a mortgage application. The president's authority to remove a Fed governor may be challenged in court. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

items.title: Trump orders removal of Fed governor Cook over mortgage fraud claims
items.standfirst: Trump says Lisa Cook sacked 'effective immediately' in unprecedented move that raises concerns for Fed's independence.
items.content: Trump says Lisa Cook sacked 'effective immediately' in unprecedented move that raises concerns for Fed's independence.

ai_summary: Donald Trump announced his intention to remove Lisa Cook from the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.
This move is seen as an escalation of Trump's criticism of the central bank.
Cook, the first Black woman on the board, would be replaced if removed.
Trump cited allegations of mortgage fraud against Cook as the reason for her removal.
European markets showed a negative reaction to Trump's announcement regarding the Fed official.

clusters.title: LIVE: World outraged over Israeli attack on Gaza hospital, journalists
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Bombs Hospital, Kills Journalists, Medics, Dozens More Across Gaza

items.title: LIVE: World outraged over Israeli attack on Gaza hospital, journalists
items.standfirst: Governments and humanitarian groups condemn Israeli attacks that killed 21 people at Gaza's Nasser Hospital.
items.content: Governments and humanitarian groups condemn Israeli attacks that killed 21 people at Gaza's Nasser Hospital.

items.title: Israel bombs hospital, kills journalists, medics, dozens more across Gaza
items.standfirst: 'Double-tap' attack on Nasser Hospital kills at least 21 Palestinians and draws global condemnation.
items.content: 'Double-tap' attack on Nasser Hospital kills at least 21 Palestinians and draws global condemnation.

items.title: Strike on Nasser Hospital: 'it's very clear this was no mistake', ICU doctor says
items.standfirst: FRANCE 24's Sharon Gaffney speaks with Dr Travis Melin, Anesthesiologist and ICU doctor in Gaza, about Monday's strike on Khan Younis' Nasser Hospital, which left 20 people dead, including 5 journalists. He says that 'it's very clear that it was no mistake'
items.content: FRANCE 24's Sharon Gaffney speaks with Dr Travis Melin, Anesthesiologist and ICU doctor in Gaza, about Monday's strike on Khan Younis' Nasser Hospital, which left 20 people dead, including 5 journalists. He says that 'it's very clear that it was no mistake'

items.title: Israeli strikes kill 22, including 5 journalists, in a Gaza hospital
items.standfirst: Israeli forces killed 22 people, including five journalists, in two strikes on Gaza's Nasser Hospital, drawing global condemnation and prompting a rare admission of regret from the Israeli government.
items.content: Israeli forces killed 22 people, including five journalists, in two strikes on Gaza's Nasser Hospital, drawing global condemnation and prompting a rare admission of regret from the Israeli government.(Image credit: Abed Rahim Khatib)

items.title: Israeli double strike on Gaza hospital - what we know
items.standfirst: Netanyahu said it was a "tragic mishap" but did little to address the apparent "double-tap" nature of the attack.
items.content: Netanyahu said it was a "tragic mishap" but did little to address the apparent "double-tap" nature of the attack.

items.title: Five journalists among 20 killed in Israeli double strike on hospital
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was a "tragic mishap" and promised a "thorough investigation".
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was a "tragic mishap" and promised a "thorough investigation".

items.title: Netanyahu says Israel 'regrets tragic mishap' after Gaza reporters killed
items.standfirst: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu expressed his regret Monday for a strike that killed 20 people, including five journalists, at a hospital in the Gaza Strip, calling it a "tragic mishap". Contributors for Reuters, the Associated Press and Al Jazeera were killed in the strike, the three news agencies have said. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu expressed his regret Monday for a strike that killed 20 people, including five journalists, at a hospital in the Gaza Strip, calling it a "tragic mishap". Contributors for Reuters, the Associated Press and Al Jazeera were killed in the strike, the three news agencies have said. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Israel bombed Gaza hospital a second time, killing rescuers, say health officials
items.standfirst: At least 20 people, including five journalists, died as they rushed to help those wounded in the first strikeIsrael bombed the main hospital in southern Gaza on Monday and then struck the same spot again as rescuers and journalists rushed to help the wounded, killing at least 20 people including five journalists, health officials said.The first strike hit the top floor of a building at the Nasser hospital, killing the Reuters journalist Hussam al-Masri and others. Journalists and rescuers then rushed to the scene to help the wounded, when a second bomb struck the same spot, 15 minutes later. Continue reading...
items.content: At least 20 people, including five journalists, died as they rushed to help those wounded in the first strikeIsrael bombed the main hospital in southern Gaza on Monday and then struck the same spot again as rescuers and journalists rushed to help the wounded, killing at least 20 people including five journalists, health officials said.The first strike hit the top floor of a building at the Nasser hospital, killing the Reuters journalist Hussam al-Masri and others. Journalists and rescuers then rushed to the scene to help the wounded, when a second bomb struck the same spot, 15 minutes later. Continue reading...

items.title: Video shows aftermath of deadly Israeli airstrike near Gaza hospital
items.standfirst: An Israeli airstrike near the Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, Gaza, has killed at least 19 people, including journalists, according to the hospital. The IDF released a statement that said: "The IDF regrets any harm to uninvolved individuals and does not target journalists as such."
items.content: An Israeli airstrike near the Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, Gaza, has killed at least 19 people, including journalists, according to the hospital. The IDF released a statement that said: "The IDF regrets any harm to uninvolved individuals and does not target journalists as such."

items.title: Five journalists among 20 killed in Israeli strikes on hospital, Gaza health ministry says
items.standfirst: Israeli strikes on a hospital in southern Gaza have killed at least 20 people, including five journalists, according to the Gaza health ministry and the media organisations the journalists worked for.
items.content: Israeli strikes on a hospital in southern Gaza have killed at least 20 people, including five journalists, according to the Gaza health ministry and the media organisations the journalists worked for.

ai_summary: An Israeli strike on Nasser Hospital in Gaza killed at least 21 people.
The attack included a "double-tap" strike, drawing global condemnation.
Five journalists were among the casualties of the hospital bombing.
Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu called the incident a "tragic mishap."
Health officials reported a second strike on the hospital, killing rescuers.

items.title: Trump says he wants another meeting with North Korea's Kim this year
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said Monday he hoped to meet North Korea’s Kim Jong Un again this year as he hosted South Korea’s dovish new leader at the White House. Hours before President Lee Jae Myung’s arrival, Trump denounced a “Purge or Revolution” in South Korea over church-related raids.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said Monday he hoped to meet North Korea’s Kim Jong Un again this year as he hosted South Korea’s dovish new leader at the White House. Hours before President Lee Jae Myung’s arrival, Trump denounced a “Purge or Revolution” in South Korea over church-related raids.

items.title: Trump says he hopes to meet Kim Jong-un and raises prospect of US taking over some South Korean land
items.standfirst: South Korean president Lee Jae Myung uses Oval Office meeting to encourage Trump to engage with North Korean leaderDonald Trump has said he wants to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, possibly this year, in an attempt to revive the failed nuclear diplomacy of his first term as US president.“I’d like to have a meeting. I look forward to meeting with Kim Jong-un in the appropriate future,” Trump said during an occasionally awkward meeting at the Oval Office with South Korea’s new president, Lee Jae Myung, in which he raised the prospect of taking ownership of South Korean land that hosts a US military base. Continue reading...
items.content: South Korean president Lee Jae Myung uses Oval Office meeting to encourage Trump to engage with North Korean leaderDonald Trump has said he wants to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, possibly this year, in an attempt to revive the failed nuclear diplomacy of his first term as US president.“I’d like to have a meeting. I look forward to meeting with Kim Jong-un in the appropriate future,” Trump said during an occasionally awkward meeting at the Oval Office with South Korea’s new president, Lee Jae Myung, in which he raised the prospect of taking ownership of South Korean land that hosts a US military base. items.title: Musk’s xAI sues Apple and OpenAI over ChatGPT and iPhone integration
items.standfirst: Tech billionaire’s move deepens feud with former ally Sam Altman
items.content: Tech billionaire’s move deepens feud with former ally Sam Altman

items.title: Musk’s AI startup sues OpenAI and Apple over anticompetitive conduct
items.standfirst: Lawsuit accuses companies of ‘conspiracy to monopolize markets for smartphones and generative AI chatbots’Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence startup xAI is suing OpenAI and Apple over allegations that they are engaging in anticompetitive conduct. The lawsuit, filed in a Texas court on Monday, accuses the companies of “a conspiracy to monopolize the markets for smartphones and generative AI chatbots”.Musk had earlier this month threatened to sue Apple and OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, after claiming that Apple was “making it impossible” for any other AI companies to reach the top spot on its app store. Musk’s xAI makes the Grok chatbot, which has struggled to become as prominent as ChatGPT. Continue reading...
items.content: Lawsuit accuses companies of ‘conspiracy to monopolize markets for smartphones and generative AI chatbots’Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence startup xAI is suing OpenAI and Apple over allegations that they are engaging in anticompetitive conduct. The lawsuit, filed in a Texas court on Monday, accuses the companies of “a conspiracy to monopolize the markets for smartphones and generative AI chatbots”.Musk had earlier this month threatened to sue Apple and OpenAI, which makes ChatGPT, after claiming that Apple was “making it impossible” for any other AI companies to reach the top spot on its app store. Musk’s xAI makes the Grok chatbot, which has struggled to become as prominent as ChatGPT. Continue reading...

items.title: Elon Musk’s xAI Sues Apple and OpenAI Over App Store Rankings
items.standfirst: The xAI lawsuit claims that Grok’s ranking below ChatGPT is a sign of allegedly monopolistic behavior.
items.content: The xAI lawsuit claims that Grok’s ranking below ChatGPT is a sign of allegedly monopolistic behavior.

items.title: Musk Sues Apple, OpenAI, Saying They Hurt AI Competition
items.standfirst: Elon Musk accused Apple Inc. and OpenAI in a lawsuit of unfairly favoring the artificial intelligence company across iPhones and thwarting competition for other chatbot makers.
items.content: Elon Musk accused Apple Inc. and OpenAI in a lawsuit of unfairly favoring the artificial intelligence company across iPhones and thwarting competition for other chatbot makers.

ai_summary: Elon Musk's xAI and X sued Apple and OpenAI, seeking billions in damages.
The lawsuit alleges Apple and OpenAI favored ChatGPT over xAI's Grok.
The suit claims the companies engaged in anticompetitive conduct.
Musk's xAI claims Grok's app store ranking is evidence of monopolistic behavior.
The lawsuit deepens the feud between Musk and OpenAI's Sam Altman.

items.title: First human screwworm case linked to travel confirmed in U.S., HHS says
items.standfirst: "The risk to public health in the United States from this introduction is very low," said HHS spokesperson Andrew Nixon.
items.content: "The risk to public health in the United States from this introduction is very low," said HHS spokesperson Andrew Nixon.

items.title: First human case of flesh-eating screwworm parasite confirmed in US
items.standfirst: New World screwworm myiasis was found in a patient who returned to the US from El Salvador, authorities say.
items.content: New World screwworm myiasis was found in a patient who returned to the US from El Salvador, authorities say.

items.title: The U.S. confirms its first human case of New World screwworm. What is it?
items.standfirst: U.S. officials confirmed a case of the flesh-eating parasite in a person who traveled from El Salvador. Screwworm typically affects cattle in South America but has spread north in recent years.
items.content: U.S. officials confirmed a case of the flesh-eating parasite in a person who traveled from El Salvador. Screwworm typically affects cattle in South America but has spread north in recent years.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: First human case of flesh-eating screwworm parasite confirmed in US
items.standfirst: HHS told Reuters patient had returned from El Salvador but beef industry said person had traveled from GuatemalaThe US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) on Sunday reported the first human case in the US of travel-associated New World screwworm, a flesh-eating parasite, from an outbreak-affected country.The case, investigated by the Maryland department of health and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), was confirmed by the CDC as New World screwworm on 4 August – and involved a patient who returned from travel to El Salvador, an HHS spokesperson, Andrew G Nixon, said in an email to Reuters. Continue reading...

items.title: Transport for London launches campaign targeting ‘headphone dodgers’
items.standfirst: Posters to appear on Elizabeth line asking passengers to be considerate and not play music or videos out loudThey are the scourge of the modern commute: passengers who play music or videos out loud. But amid widespread disapproval from fellow travellers, Transport for London (TfL) is trying to appeal to the better nature of “headphone dodgers” by asking them to “be considerate” and plug in.The new posters, which will start to appear on the Elizabeth line this week – and on other TfL services, including London buses, in the autumn – remind travellers to use headphones when listening to music or making calls. Continue reading...

clusters.title: French PM's job on line with call for confidence vote
clusters.neutral_headline: French Prime Minister's Job on Line with Call for Confidence Vote

items.title: French PM's job on line with call for confidence vote
items.standfirst: France's embattled Prime Minister Francois Bayrou said on Monday his government would request a vote of confidence on September 8, seeking parliamentary backing for his battle against soaring public debt. The move is high-risk for both Bayrou, whose minority government could be toppled, and President Emmanuel Macron, now on his sixth prime minister since taking office in 2017. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris-Trent reports.
items.content: France's embattled Prime Minister Francois Bayrou said on Monday his government would request a vote of confidence on September 8, seeking parliamentary backing for his battle against soaring public debt. The move is high-risk for both Bayrou, whose minority government could be toppled, and President Emmanuel Macron, now on his sixth prime minister since taking office in 2017. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris-Trent reports.

items.title: French prime minister to face potential ousting in high-stakes confidence vote
items.standfirst: François Bayrou to seek parliamentary backing for his unpopular plans to shore up France’s public finances France’s embattled prime minister looks likely to be ousted and his government toppled next month in a high-stakes confidence vote that could plunge the EU’s second-biggest economy into even deeper political crisis.François Bayrou said on Monday that he would seek parliamentary backing for his unpopular plans to shore up France’s ailing public finances on 8 September, asking deputies to “confirm the scale” of spending cuts he says are needed to save €44bn (£38bn) a year. Continue reading...
items.content: François Bayrou to seek parliamentary backing for his unpopular plans to shore up France’s public finances France’s embattled prime minister looks likely to be ousted and his government toppled next month in a high-stakes confidence vote that could plunge the EU’s second-biggest economy into even deeper political crisis.François Bayrou said on Monday that he would seek parliamentary backing for his unpopular plans to shore up France’s ailing public finances on 8 September, asking deputies to “confirm the scale” of spending cuts he says are needed to save €44bn (£38bn) a year. Continue reading...

items.title: French opposition parties vow to overthrow Bayrou government in Sept 8 confidence vote
items.standfirst: France’s opposition parties lined up Monday to reject Prime Minister François Bayrou’s high-stakes bid for a September 8 confidence vote on his budget-cutting agenda, signaling they will use the showdown to try to topple his minority government. The political uncertainty has shaken markets and raised the spectre of French President Emmanuel Macron being forced into a snap election or a caretaker administration.
items.content: France’s opposition parties lined up Monday to reject Prime Minister François Bayrou’s high-stakes bid for a September 8 confidence vote on his budget-cutting agenda, signaling they will use the showdown to try to topple his minority government. The political uncertainty has shaken markets and raised the spectre of French President Emmanuel Macron being forced into a snap election or a caretaker administration.

items.title: Mushroom murderer Erin Patterson left me 'half alive', sole survivor says
items.standfirst: The sole surviving guest of a lunch where three others died after being served food laced with toxic mushrooms has told an Australian court that the actions of murderer Erin Patterson have left him feeling "half alive".
items.content: The sole surviving guest of a lunch where three others died after being served food laced with toxic mushrooms has told an Australian court that the actions of murderer Erin Patterson have left him feeling "half alive".

ai_summary: Erin Patterson is accused of murdering three people with toxic mushrooms.
The sole survivor of the lunch testified in court about the impact.
Family members of the victims confronted Patterson in court.
The survivor stated Patterson's actions left him feeling "half alive".
The case involves the poisoning of guests at a lunch.
